content: Friday May 29, 2009 6:30:15 EDT BEDFORD, Va. — The president of the National D-Day Memorial foundation says it may be forced to close the memorial. William McIntosh said Thursday the memorial needs an infusion of cash or a new owner. He says the memorial’s big problem is a lack of donations, due to the economy. The memorial gets about $600,000 a year from visitors, but counts on donations for another $1.6 million annually. The memorial honors the Allied invasion of Nazi-occupied France during World War II. The invasion was the largest land, air and sea operation in military history.
reply: Friday May 29, 2009 6:30:15 EDT BEDFORD, Va. — The president of the National D-Day Memorial foundation says it may be forced to close the memorial. The invasion was the largest land, air and sea operation in military history.

content: I also searched the web site and could find nothing to indicate an imminent closing. Perhaps, as with many non-profit organizations given the current economic crises, they are experiencing a decline in contributions.
reply: I also searched the web site and could find nothing to indicate an imminent closing. Perhaps, as with many non-profit organizations given the current economic crises, they are experiencing a decline in contributions.
title: National D-Day Memorial may close

content: AliBubba - Bedford, Virginia, lost more of its sons in the D-Day invasion than any other place in the US. The memorial there was built with private funds and was dedicated sometime in the early '90s, I believe. Sen. Robert Dole attended, as he was one of the primary backers of the memorial. The one in NOLA was originally where the duck boats, used in the landings, were built. To my knowledge, that is not a public memorial/museum, either. The WWII Memorial, on the Mall in Washington DC, is the official publicly-owned memorial to WWII - not just D-Day.
reply: AliBubba - Bedford, Virginia, lost more of its sons in the D-Day invasion than any other place in the US. The memorial there was built with private funds and was dedicated sometime in the early '90s, I believe. Sen. Robert Dole attended, as he was one of the primary backers of the memorial. The one in NOLA was originally where the duck boats, used in the landings, were built. To my knowledge, that is not a public memorial/museum, either. The WWII Memorial, on the Mall in Washington DC, is the official publicly-owned memorial to WWII - not just D-Day.
title: National D-Day Memorial may close

content: The National Women's Service Memorial at Arlington may also close due to lack of funding. Many national museums & memorials are not 100% funded by the federal government these days. They are heavily dependent on private donations. Those have dropped off during the recession.
reply: The National Women's Service Memorial at Arlington may also close due to lack of funding. Many national museums & memorials are not 100% funded by the federal government these days. They are heavily dependent on private donations. Those have dropped off during the recession.
title: National D-Day Memorial may close

content: That would be WIMSA: Women in Military Service to America, and yes - it too is in dire financial straits. I think that because of its location - at the end of Memorial Bridge, just at the entrance to Arlington National Cemetery - many people tend to think it is part of ANC and therefore federally funded. It is not; the location was given to the WIMSA foundation since that space was deteriorating and WIMSA promised to refurbish it - which it did.
reply: That would be WIMSA: Women in Military Service to America, and yes - it too is in dire financial straits. content: AliBubba - Bedford, Virginia, lost more of its sons in the D-Day invasion than any other place in the US. The memorial there was built with private funds and was dedicated sometime in the early '90s, I believe. Sen. Robert Dole attended, as he was one of the primary backers of the memorial. The one in NOLA was originally where the duck boats, used in the landings, were built. To my knowledge, that is not a public memorial/museum, either. The WWII Memorial, on the Mall in Washington DC, is the official publicly-owned memorial to WWII - not just D-Day.
reply: AliBubba - Bedford, Virginia, lost more of its sons in the D-Day invasion than any other place in the US. The memorial there was built with private funds and was dedicated sometime in the early '90s, I believe. Sen. Robert Dole attended, as he was one of the primary backers of the memorial. The one in NOLA was originally where the duck boats, used in the landings, were built. To my knowledge, that is not a public memorial/museum, either. The WWII Memorial, on the Mall in Washington DC, is the official publicly-owned memorial to WWII - not just D-Day.
title: National D-Day Memorial may close

content: That would be WIMSA: Women in Military Service to America, and yes - it too is in dire financial straits. I think that because of its location - at the end of Memorial Bridge, just at the entrance to Arlington National Cemetery - many people tend to think it is part of ANC and therefore federally funded. It is not; the location was given to the WIMSA foundation since that space was deteriorating and WIMSA promised to refurbish it - which it did.
